Article.ArticleTitle: The mimics of N<sup>ε</sup>-acyl-lysine derived from cysteine as sirtuin inhibitors.

AbstractText: Sirtuin inhibitors as physiological research tools and therapeutic potentials have caught many attentions in last decades. The mimics of acyl lysine have been approved to be a very efficient strategy for development of mechanism-based sirtuin inhibitors. In current study, a novel scaffold of l-S-(3-carboxamidopropyl) cysteine (l-CAPC) has been exploited for design and synthesis of sirtuin inhibitors. As a result, the mimics of N<sup>ε</sup>-acyl-lysine derived from cysteine including small molecules (5a-m) and peptides (9a-m) have been synthesized. Among these, the peptides 9g and 9h were found to be the most inhibitory potency and selectivity against SIRT2.
